|pattern_so3 =_cfc1920t |leftarm3 = 050505 |body3 = 050505 |rightarm3 = 050505 |shorts3 = 050505 |socks3 = FF3900 }} '''Chelsea Football Club''' are an English professional [[Association football|football]] club based in [[Fulham]], [[London]]. Founded in 1905, they compete in the [[Premier League]], the top division of [[Football in England|English football]]. Chelsea are among [[List of football clubs in England by competitive honours won|England's most successful clubs]]; they have been league champions six times and won over thirty competitive honours, including six European trophies. Their home ground is [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]].<ref name="capacity">{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/the-club/about-chelsea-football-club/general-club-info.html |title=General Club Information |website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=13 August 2015}}</ref>
Chelsea won their first major honour, the [[List of English football champions|League Championship]], in [[1954–55 Chelsea F.C. season|1955]]. They won the [[FA Cup]] for the first time in 1970 and their first European honour, the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]], in 1971. After a period of decline in the late 1970s and 1980s, the club enjoyed a revival in the 1990s and had more success in cup competitions. The past two decades have been the most successful in Chelsea's history: they won five of their six league titles and the [[UEFA Champions League]] during this period.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/about-chelsea/history/trophy-cabinet |title=Trophy Cabinet |website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=23 May 2018 }}</ref> Chelsea are one of [[UEFA club competition records and statistics#List of teams to have won the three main European club competitions|five clubs]] to have won all three of UEFA's main club competitions, and the only London club to have won the Champions League.
Chelsea's home kit colours are royal blue shirts and shorts with white socks. The club's crest features a ceremonial lion rampant regardant holding a staff.<ref name="new crest">{{cite news |title=Chelsea centenary crest unveiled |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/4008257.stm |work=BBC Sport |date=12 November 2004 |accessdate=2 January 2007 }}</ref> The club have rivalries with neighbouring teams [[Arsenal F.C.–Chelsea F.C. rivalry|Arsenal]] and [[Chelsea F.C.–Tottenham Hotspur F.C. rivalry|Tottenham Hotspur]], and a historic rivalry with [[Chelsea F.C.–Leeds United F.C. rivalry|Leeds United]]. Based on attendance figures, the club have the sixth-largest fanbase in England.<ref name="All-time attendance">{{cite web|title=All Time League Attendance Records|url=http://www.nufc.com/2015-16html/attendance-all-time.html|publisher=nufc.com|accessdate=6 April 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406083542/http://www.nufc.com/2015-16html/attendance-all-time.html|archivedate=6 April 2016|date=22 September 2015}} Please note, pre-war figures come from unreliable sources.</ref> In terms of club value, Chelsea are the [[Forbes' list of the most valuable football clubs|sixth most valuable football club in the world]], worth £2.13 billion ($2.576 billion), and are the [[Deloitte Football Money League|eighth highest-earning]] football club in the world, with earnings of over €428 million in the 2017–18 season.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mikeozanian/2018/06/12/the-worlds-most-valuable-soccer-teams-2018/#3dddb7c845c8|title=The World's Most Valuable Soccer Teams 2018|last=Ozanian|first=Mike|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-06-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www2.deloitte.com/uk/en/pages/sports-business-group/articles/deloitte-football-money-league.html|title=Deloitte Football Money League 2018|date=23 January 2018|accessdate=23 January 2018|publisher=Deloitte}}</ref> Since 2003, Chelsea have been owned by Russian billionaire [[Roman Abramovich]].<ref name="takeover">{{cite news |title=Russian businessman buys Chelsea |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/3036838.stm |work=BBC Sport |date=2 July 2003 |accessdate=11 February 2007 }}</ref>
==History== {{Main|History of Chelsea F.C.}} [[File:Chelsea Team 1905.jpg|thumb|250px|The [[History of Chelsea F.C.|first Chelsea team]] in September 1905]]
In 1904, [[Gus Mears]] acquired the [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] athletics stadium with the aim of turning it into a football ground. An offer to lease it to nearby [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] was turned down, so Mears opted to found his own club to use the stadium. As there was already a team named Fulham in the borough, the name of the adjacent borough of [[Metropolitan Borough of Chelsea|Chelsea]] was chosen for the new club; names like ''Kensington FC'', ''Stamford Bridge FC'' and ''London FC'' were also considered.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |page=55}}</ref> Chelsea were founded on 10 March 1905 at The Rising Sun pub (now The Butcher's Hook),<ref name="teamhistory"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/the-club/club-history/1900.html|title=The Birth of a Club|publisher=Chelsea FC|date=30 September 2004|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> opposite the present-day main entrance to the ground on [[Fulham Road]], and were elected to the Football League shortly afterwards.
Chelsea won promotion to the First Division in their second season, and yo-yoed between the First and Second Divisions in their early years. They reached the [[1915 FA Cup Final]], where they lost to [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] at Old Trafford, and finished third in the First Division in 1920, the club's best league campaign to that point.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/1800262 |title=Team History – 1905–29 |website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=23 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718071312/http://www.chelseafc.com/page/TeamHistory/0%2C%2C10268~1800262%2C00.html |archivedate=18 July 2011 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Chelsea had a reputation for signing star players<ref name="glanville">{{cite news |date=10 January 2004 |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/article992039.ece |title=Little sign of change for Chelsea and their impossible dreams |work=The Times |location=UK|accessdate=15 March 2009 |first=Brian |last=Glanville |author-link=Brian Glanville}} {{registration required}}</ref> and attracted and [[1919–20 in English football|1919–20]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://european-football-statistics.co.uk/attn/england/aveeng1920.htm|title=Historical attendances|publisher=European Football <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/page/TeamHistory/0,,10268~910883,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120720222638/http://www.chelseafc.com/page/TeamHistory/0%2C%2C10268~910883%2C00.html |archivedate=20 July 2012 |title=Between the Wars – Big Names and Big Crowds |website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=7 May 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref> They were FA Cup semi-finalists in [[FA Cup 1919-20|1920]] and [[FA Cup 1931-32|1932]] and remained in the First Division throughout the 1930s, but success eluded the club in the inter-war years.
Former [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] and England centre-forward [[Ted Drake]] was appointed manager in 1952 and proceeded to modernise the club. He removed the club's [[Chelsea pensioner]] crest, improved the youth set-up and training regime, rebuilt the side with shrewd signings from the lower divisions and amateur leagues, and led Chelsea to their first major trophy success – the League championship – in [[1954–55 Chelsea F.C. season|1954–55]]. The following season saw UEFA create the [[UEFA Champions League|European Champions' Cup]], but after objections from [[The Football League]] and the [[The Football Association|FA]], Chelsea were persuaded to withdraw from the competition before it started.<ref>{{cite news |date=27 April 2005 |url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/sport/football/europe/article2327902.ece |title=The great Chelsea surrender |work=The Times |location=UK |accessdate=29 December 2006 |first=Brian |last=Glanville |author-link=Brian Glanville}}</ref> Chelsea failed to build on this success, and spent the remainder of the 1950s in mid-table. Drake was dismissed in 1961 and replaced by player-coach [[Tommy Docherty]].
[[File:ChelseaFC League Performance.svg|thumb|left|Chart showing the progress of Chelsea's league finishes from 1906 to the present]]
Docherty built a new team around the group of talented young players emerging from the club's youth set-up and Chelsea challenged for honours throughout the 1960s, enduring several near-misses. They were on course for a treble of League, FA Cup and League Cup going into the final stages of the 1964–65 season, winning the League Cup but faltering late on in the other two.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography – The Definitive Story of the First 100 Years|publisher=Headline Book Publishing Ltd|year=2006|isbn=978-0-7553-1466-9 |page=196}}</ref> In three seasons the side were beaten in three major semi-finals and were FA Cup runners-up. Under Docherty's successor, [[Dave Sexton]], Chelsea won the [[1970 FA Cup Final|FA Cup in 1970]], beating [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] 2–1 in a final replay. The following year, Chelsea took their first European honour, a [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] triumph, with another replayed win, this time over [[Real Madrid CF|Real Madrid]] in Athens.
The late 1970s through to the '80s was a turbulent period for Chelsea. An ambitious redevelopment of Stamford Bridge threatened the financial stability of the club,<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=84–87}}</ref> star players were sold and the team were relegated. Further problems were caused by a notorious [[hooliganism|hooligan]] element among the support, which was to plague the club throughout the decade.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=143–157}}</ref> In 1982, Chelsea were, at the nadir of their fortunes, acquired by [[Ken Bates]] for the nominal sum of £1, although by now the Stamford Bridge freehold had been sold to property developers, meaning the club faced losing their home.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=89–90}}</ref> On the pitch, the team had fared little better, coming close to relegation to the [[Football League Third Division|Third Division]] for the first time, but in 1983 manager [[John Neal (footballer, born 1932)|John Neal]] put together an impressive new team for minimal outlay. Chelsea won the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] title in 1983–84 and established themselves in the top division with two top-six finishes, before being relegated again in 1988. The club bounced back immediately by winning the Second Division championship in 1988–89.
[[File:Chelsea UCL Winners 2012.jpg|thumb|250px|Chelsea players celebrate their first [[2012 UEFA Champions League Final|UEFA Champions League title]] against [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]] (2012).]]
After a long-running legal battle, Bates reunited the stadium freehold with the club in 1992 by doing a deal with the banks of the property developers, who had been bankrupted by a market crash.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=90–91}}</ref> Chelsea's form in the new Premier League was unconvincing, although they did reach the [[1994 FA Cup Final]]. The appointment of [[Ruud Gullit]] as player-manager in 1996 began an upturn in the team's fortunes. He added several top international players to the side and led the club to their first major honour since 1971, the [[1997 FA Cup Final|FA Cup]]. Gullit was replaced by [[Gianluca Vialli]], whose reign saw Chelsea win the [[1998 Football League Cup Final|League Cup]], the [[1998 UEFA Cup Winners' Cup Final|UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] and the [[1998 UEFA Super Cup|UEFA Super Cup in 1998]], and the [[2000 FA Cup Final|FA Cup in 2000]]. They also mounted a strong title challenge in 1998–99, finishing four points behind champions Manchester United, and made their first appearance in the [[UEFA Champions League]]. Vialli was sacked in favour of [[Claudio Ranieri]], who guided Chelsea to the [[2002 FA Cup Final]] and Champions League qualification in 2002–03.
In July 2003, Bates sold Chelsea to Russian billionaire [[Roman Abramovich]] for £140 million.<ref name="takeover"/> Over £100 million was spent on new players, but Ranieri was unable to deliver any trophies,<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea sack Ranieri |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/3742477.stm |work=BBC Sport |date=1 June 2004 |accessdate=20 May 2012 }}</ref> and was replaced by [[José Mourinho]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea appoint Mourinho |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/3765263.stm |work=BBC Sport |date=2 June 2004 |accessdate=20 May 2012 }}</ref> Under Mourinho, Chelsea became the fifth English team to win back-to-back league championships since the Second World War ([[2004–05 FA Premier League|2004–05]] and [[2005–06 FA Premier League|2005–06]]),<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sportinglife.com/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer/06/03/12/SOCCER_Chelsea.html&TEAMHD=soccer |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120603160253/http://www.sportinglife.com/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer%2F06%2F03%2F12%2FSOCCER_Chelsea.html&TEAMHD=soccer |archivedate=3 June 2012 |title=Terry Eyes Back-to-Back Titles |work=Sporting Life |accessdate=22 January 2007 |first=Matt |last=Barlow |date=12 March 2006 |url-status=dead }}</ref> in addition to winning an FA Cup ([[2007 FA Cup Final|2007]]) and two League Cups ([[2005 Football League Cup Final|2005]] and [[2007 Football League Cup Final|2007]]). After a poor start to the 2007–2008 season, Mourinho was replaced by [[Avram Grant]],<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea name Grant as new manager |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/7004083.stm |work=BBC Sport |date=20 September 2007 |accessdate=21 September 2007 }}</ref> who led the club to their first [[2008 UEFA Champions League Final|UEFA Champions League final]], which they lost on penalties to [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].
In 2009, under caretaker manager [[Guus Hiddink]], Chelsea won another [[2009 FA Cup Final|FA Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea 2–1 Everton |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/fa_cup/8060989.stm |work=BBC Sport |date=30 May 2009 |accessdate=1 June 2009 }}</ref> In [[2009–10 in English football|2009–10]], his successor [[Carlo Ancelotti]] led them to their first [[2009–10 Premier League|Premier League]] and [[2010 FA Cup Final|FA Cup]] [[Double (association football)|Double]], also becoming the first English top-flight club to score 100 league goals in a season since [[1962–63 in English football|1963]].<ref name="Wigan80">{{cite news |title=Chelsea 8–0 Wigan news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2017/may/12/west-brom-v-chelsea-blues-bid-to-win-premier-league-title-live|title=Chelsea crowned Premier League champions after win at West Brom – as |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=17 June 2019}}</ref> under whom Chelsea reached the [[2018-19 EFL Cup|League Cup final]], which they lost on penalties to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester |accessdate=17 June 2019}}</ref> and won the [[2019 UEFA Europa League Final|Europa League]] for a second time, beating [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] 4–1 in the final. Sarri then left the club to become manager of [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] and was then replaced by former Chelsea player [[Frank Lampard]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Frank Lampard confirmed as new Chelsea boss|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/news/2019/07/04/frank-lampard-returns-to-chelsea|date=4 July 2019|work= Chelsea FC|accessdate=18 July 2019}}</ref>
==Stadium== {{Main|Stamford Bridge (stadium)}} [[File:Stamford Bridge - West Stand.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], West Stand]] Chelsea have only had one home ground, Stamford Bridge, where they have played since the team's foundation. It was officially opened on 28 April 1877 and for the first 28 years of its existence, it was used almost exclusively by the [[London Athletic Club]] as an arena for athletics meetings and not at all for football. In 1904 the ground was acquired by businessman [[Gus Mears]] and his brother [[Joseph Mears|Joseph]], who had also purchased nearby land (formerly a large market garden) with the aim of staging football matches on the now 12.5 acre (51,000 m²) site.<ref name="stadium"/> Stamford Bridge was designed for the Mears family by the noted football architect [[Archibald Leitch]], who had also designed [[Ibrox Stadium|Ibrox]], [[Craven Cottage]] and [[Hampden Park]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=69–71}}</ref> Most football clubs were founded first, and then sought grounds in which to play, but Chelsea were founded for Stamford Bridge.
Starting with an open bowl-like design and one grandstand with seating, Stamford Bridge had an original capacity of around 100,000, making it the second biggest stadium in England after [[Crystal Palace National Sports Centre|Crystal Palace]].<ref name="stadium"/> The early 1930s saw the construction of a terrace on the southern part of the ground with a roof that covered around one fifth of the stand. As the roof resembled that of a corrugated iron shed, the stand eventually became known as the "Shed End", although it is unknown who first coined this name. Starting in the 1960s, it became known as the home of Chelsea's most loyal and vocal supporters.<ref name="stadium">{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/page/StadiumHistory/0,,10268,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120512170633/http://www.chelseafc.com/page/StadiumHistory/0%2C%2C10268%2C00.html |archivedate=12 May 2012 |title=Stadium History – Introduction |website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=20 May 2012 |url-status=dead
}}</ref> In 1939, another small seated stand was added, the North Stand, which remained until its demolition in 1975.<ref name="stadium"/>
In the early 1970s, the club's owners announced a modernisation of Stamford Bridge with plans for a state-of-the-art 50,000 all-seater stadium.<ref name="stadium"/> Work began in 1972 but the project was beset with problems and ultimately only the East Stand was completed; the cost brought the club close to bankruptcy, culminating in the [[Fee simple|freehold]] being sold to property developers. Following a long legal battle, it was not until the mid-1990s that Chelsea's future at the stadium was secured and renovation work resumed.<ref name="stadium"/> The north, west and southern parts of the ground were converted into all-seater stands and moved closer to the pitch, a process completed by 2001. The East Stand was retained from the 1970s development. In 1996, the north stand was renamed the [[Matthew Harding]] stand, after the club director and benefactor who was killed in a helicopter crash earlier that year.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/news/2018/10/22/matthew-harding-remembered |title=Matthew Harding Remembered |work=chelseafc.com |accessdate=1 July 2019}}</ref> [[File:Chelsea-ilkmac.jpg|left|frame|Chelsea ''vs.'' [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] at Stamford Bridge on 23 September 1905; Chelsea won 1–0.]] When Stamford Bridge was redeveloped in the [[Ken Bates|Bates]] era many additional features were added to the complex including two [[Millennium & Copthorne Hotels|Millennium & Copthorne]] hotels, apartments, bars, restaurants, the Chelsea Megastore, and an interactive visitor attraction called Chelsea World of Sport. The intention was that these facilities would provide extra revenue to support the football side of the business, but they were less successful than hoped and before the Abramovich takeover in 2003 the debt taken on to finance them was a major burden on the club. Soon after the takeover a decision was taken to drop the "Chelsea Village" brand and refocus on Chelsea as a football club. However, the stadium is sometimes still referred to as part of ''"Chelsea Village"'' or ''"The Village"''.
The Stamford Bridge [[Freehold (law)|freehold]], the [[Association football pitch|pitch]], the turnstiles and Chelsea's [[naming rights]] are now owned by [[Chelsea Pitch Owners]], a non-profit organisation in which fans are the shareholders. The CPO was created to ensure the stadium could never again be sold to developers. As a condition for using the Chelsea FC name, the club has to play its first team matches at Stamford Bridge, which means that if the club moves to a new stadium, they may have to change their name.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=91–92}}</ref> Chelsea's [[Cobham Training Centre|training ground]] is located in [[Cobham, Surrey]]. Chelsea moved to Cobham in 2004. Their previous training ground in [[Harlington, London|Harlington]] was taken over by [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|QPR]] in 2005.<ref>{{cite news |title=QPR take over Chelsea training ground |first=Wayne |last=Veysey |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/qpr-take-over-chelsea-training-ground-7179619.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025213214/http://www.standard.co.uk/sport/qpr-take-over-chelsea-training-ground-7179619.html |archivedate=25 October 2012 |work=London Evening Standard |date=24 May 2005 |accessdate=24 June 2009 }}</ref> The new training facilities in Cobham were completed in 2007.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea's new training ground for the future |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/london/content/articles/2007/07/05/chelsea_ground_feature.shtml |publisher=BBC London |date=5 July 2007 |accessdate=24 June 2009 }}</ref> [[File:Stamford Bridge, 30 June 2011 cropped.jpg|thumb|230px|right|Aerial view of present-day [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]]]] Stamford Bridge hosted the [[FA Cup Final]] from 1920 to 1922,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/TheFACup/FACompetitions/TheFACup/History/CupFinalResults |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20120516005522/http://thefa.com/Competitions/FACompetitions/TheFACup/History/CupFinalResults |url-status=dead |archive-date=16 May 2012 |title=Cup Final Statistics |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=18 February 2011 }}</ref> has held ten [[FA Cup Semi-finals]] (most recently in [[1977–78 FA Cup|1978]]), ten [[FA Community Shield|FA Charity Shield]] matches (the last in [[1970 FA Charity Shield|1970]]), and three [[England national football team|England international]] matches, the last in 1932; ==Crest and colours==
===Crest=== [[File:Chelsea Crest 1953.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Chelsea's crest from 1953–1986; the present day crest was modelled on this one.]] Chelsea have had four main [[crest (sports)|crests]], which all underwent minor variations. The first, adopted when the club was founded, was the image of a [[Chelsea pensioner]], the army veterans who reside at the nearby [[Royal Hospital Chelsea]]. This contributed to the club's original "pensioner" nickname, and remained for the next half-century, though it never appeared on the shirts. When [[Ted Drake]] became Chelsea manager in 1952, he began to modernise the club. Believing the Chelsea pensioner crest to be old-fashioned, he insisted that it be replaced.<ref name="crest">{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |page=42}}</ref> A stop-gap badge which comprised the initials C.F.C. was adopted for a year. In 1953, the club crest was changed to an upright blue lion looking backwards and holding a [[crosier|staff]]. It was based on elements in the [[coat of arms]] of the [[Metropolitan Borough of Chelsea]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.civicheraldry.co.uk/lcc.html#chelsea%20bc |title=Chelsea Metropolitan Borough Council |work=Civic Heraldry of England and Wales |accessdate=21 January 2007}}</ref> with the "lion rampant regardant" taken from the arms of then club president [[William Cadogan, 7th Earl Cadogan|Viscount Chelsea]] and the staff from the [[Westminster Abbey|Abbots of Westminster]], former Lords of the Manor of Chelsea. It also featured three red roses, to represent England, and two footballs.<ref name="crest"/> This was the first Chelsea crest to appear on the shirts, in the early 1960s.
In 1986, with [[Ken Bates]] now owner of the club, Chelsea's crest was changed again as part of another attempt to modernise and because the old rampant lion badge could not be trademarked.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/the-club/club-history/1980.html |title=1980s Summary |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref> The new badge featured a more naturalistic non-heraldic lion, in white and not blue, standing over the C.F.C. initials. This lasted for the next 19 years, with some modifications such as the use of different colours, including red from 1987 to 1995, and yellow from 1995 until 1999, before the white returned.<ref name="HFK">{{cite web|title=Historical Kits – Chelsea |url=http://www.historicalkits.co.uk/Chelsea/Chelsea.htm |first=Dave |last=Moor |publisher=Historical Kits |accessdate=28 September 2011}}</ref> With the new ownership of [[Roman Abramovich]], and the club's centenary approaching, combined with demands from fans for the popular 1950s badge to be restored, it was decided that the crest should be changed again in 2005. The new crest was officially adopted for the start of the [[2005–06 in English football|2005–06]] season and marked a return to the older design, used from 1953 to 1986, featuring a blue heraldic lion holding a staff. For the centenary season this was accompanied by the words '100 YEARS' and 'CENTENARY 2005–2006' on the top and bottom of the crest respectively.<ref name="new crest"/>
===Colours=== {{Football kit box |align = right |pattern_la = |pattern_b = _chelsea1905h |pattern_ra = |pattern_so =_2bluestripes |leftarm = 96C8A2 |body = 96C8A2 |rightarm = 96C8A2 |shorts = FFFFFF |socks = 000000 |title = Chelsea's first home colours (1905 – c. 1912) }} {{Commons|Chelsea F.C. kits}}
Chelsea have always worn blue shirts, although they originally used the paler [[eton blue]], which was taken from the racing colours of then club president, [[Earl Cadogan]], and was worn with white shorts and dark blue or black socks.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.historicalkits.co.uk/Chelsea/Chelsea.htm |title=Chelsea – Historical Football Kits |work=Historical Kits |accessdate=26 June 2012 }}</ref> The light blue shirts were replaced by a royal blue version in around 1912.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |title=Chelsea Football Club: The Official History in Pictures|year=2006|isbn=978-0-7553-1467-6}} p. 212</ref> In the 1960s Chelsea manager [[Tommy Docherty]] changed the kit again, switching to blue shorts (which have remained ever since) and white socks, believing it made the club's colours more modern and distinctive, since no other major side used that combination; this kit was first worn during the 1964–65 season.<ref>{{cite book |last=Mears |first=Brian |title=Chelsea: Football Under the Blue Flag|publisher=Mainstream Sport|year=2002|isbn=978-1-84018-658-1 |page=42 }}</ref> Since then Chelsea have always worn white socks with their home kit apart from a short spell from 1985 to 1992, when blue socks were reintroduced.
Chelsea's away colours are usually all yellow or all white with blue trim. More recently, the club have had a number of black or dark blue away kits which alternate every year.<ref name="change kits">{{cite web |url=http://www.historicalkits.co.uk/Chelsea/Chelsea-change-kits.html |title=Chelsea Change Kits |work=Historical Kits |accessdate=7 December 2015 }}</ref> As with most teams, they have also had some more unusual ones. At Docherty's behest, in the 1966 FA Cup semi-final they wore blue and black stripes, based on [[Inter Milan]]'s kit.<ref>{{cite book |last=Mears|first=Brian |title=Chelsea: Football Under the Blue Flag|publisher=|year=2002|page=58 }}</ref> In the mid-1970s, the away strip was a red, white and green kit inspired by the [[Golden Team|Hungarian national side]] of the 1950s.<ref>{{cite book |last=Batty |first=Clive|title=Kings of the King's Road: The Great Chelsea Team of the 60s & 70s|publisher=Vision Sports Publishing|year=2007|isbn=978-1-905326-22-8 |page=244}}</ref> Other memorable away kits include an all jade strip worn from 1986–89, red and white diamonds from 1990–92, graphite and tangerine from 1994–96, and luminous yellow from 2007–08.<ref name="change kits"/> The graphite and tangerine strip has appeared in lists of the worst football kits ever.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/aug/12/sport.obsmagspecial9|title=Eyes wide shut|work=The Observer|date=12 August 2007|accessdate=7 December 2015}}</ref>
==Support== [[File:Chelsea defend corner.jpg|thumb|250px|Chelsea fans at a match against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], on 11 March 2006]] Chelsea are among the most widely supported football clubs in the world.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/511644/Chelsea-are-a-more-universally-loved-club-Blues-chief-lauds-400million-fan-base |title=Chelsea are a more universally loved club! Blues chief lauds 400million fan base |last=Anderson |first=Jamie |work=Daily Express |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://talksport.com/magazine/big-picture/2011-10-13/worlds-most-popular-football-club-revealed-man-united-liverpool-arsenal-barca-real-or-chelsea|title=The world's most popular football club revealed: Man United, Liverpool F.C., Arsenal F.C., Barca, Real or Chelsea?|work=talkSPORT|date=2011-10-13}}</ref> They have the sixth highest average all-time attendance in [[Football in England|English football]],<ref name="All-time attendance"/> and regularly attract over 40,000 fans to Stamford Bridge; they were the seventh best-supported [[Premier League]] team in the 2013–14 season, with an average gate of 41,572.<ref name="14/15 attendances">{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerstats.com/attendance.asp?league=england|title=Attendances (at home)|publisher=Soccerstats.com|accessdate=21 May 2017}}</ref> Chelsea's traditional fanbase comes from all over the [[Greater London]] area including working-class parts such as [[Hammersmith]] and [[Battersea]], wealthier areas like Chelsea and [[Kensington]], and from the [[home counties]]. There are also numerous official supporters clubs in the United Kingdom and all over the world.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/supporters-clubs |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140323222258/http://www.chelseafc.com/supporters-clubs |archivedate=23 March 2014 |title=Supporters Clubs Map |work=chelseafc.com |accessdate=23 March 2014}}</ref> Between 2007 and 2012, Chelsea were ranked fourth worldwide in annual replica kit sales, with an average of 910,000.<ref>{{cite news |title=EXCLUSIVE: Manchester United and Real Madrid top global shirt sale charts |url=http://www.sportingintelligence.com/2012/10/08/exclusive-manchester-united-and-real-madrid-top-global-shirt-sale-charts-081001/ |work=Sporting Intelligence|date=8 October 2012 |accessdate=8 October 2012}}</ref> As of 2018, Chelsea had 72.2 million followers on social media, the fourth highest among football clubs.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/the-20-most-popular-rich-list-football-teams-on-social-media-2018-8?r=US&IR=T#5-bayern-munich-657-million-followers-16 |title=The 20 most popular rich-list football teams on social media |work=Business Insider |accessdate=23 June 2019}}</ref>
At matches, Chelsea fans sing [[football chants|chants]] such as "[[Carefree (chant)|Carefree]]" (to the tune of "[[Lord of the Dance (hymn)|Lord of the Dance]]", whose lyrics were probably written by supporter Mick Greenaway),<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |page=150}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://fanchants.com/football-songs/chelsea-chants/carefree/ |title="Carefree" audio sample |publisher=Fanchants.com |accessdate=3 September 2011}}</ref> "Ten Men Went to Mow", "We All Follow the Chelsea" (to the tune of "[[Land of Hope and Glory]]"), "Zigga Zagga", and the celebratory "Celery". The latter is often accompanied by fans throwing celery at each other, although the vegetable was banned inside Stamford Bridge after an incident involving [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] midfielder [[Cesc Fàbregas]] at the [[2007 Football League Cup Final|2007 League Cup Final]].<ref>{{cite news |date=17 April 2002 |url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/News_Story/0,1563,685859,00.html |title=Fans sent spinning after tossing salad |work=The Guardian |accessdate=1 January 2007 |first=Scott |last=Murray}}</ref> During the 1970s and 1980s in particular, Chelsea supporters were associated with [[Football (soccer) hooliganism|football hooliganism]]. The club's "[[Football hooliganism|football firm]]", originally known as the Chelsea Shed Boys, and subsequently as the [[Chelsea Headhunters]], were nationally notorious for football violence, alongside hooligan firms from other clubs such as [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]'s [[Inter City Firm]] and [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]]'s [[Millwall Bushwackers|Bushwackers]], before, during and after matches.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/hooligans/1962503.stm |title=Making a new start |work=BBC News |accessdate=21 January 2007 |date=2 May 2002}}</ref> The increase of hooligan incidents in the 1980s led chairman Ken Bates to propose erecting an electric fence to deter them from invading the pitch, a proposal that the [[Greater London Council]] rejected.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/3037508.stm |title=Bates: Chelsea's driving force |work=BBC Sport |accessdate=21 January 2007 |date=2 July 2003}}</ref>
Since the 1990s, there has been a marked decline in crowd trouble at matches, as a result of stricter policing, [[Closed-circuit television|CCTV]] in grounds and the advent of [[All-seater stadium|all-seater stadia]].<ref>{{cite news |date=2 June 1998 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/special_report/1998/hooligans/60146.stm |title=Soccer hooliganism: Made in England, but big abroad |work=BBC News |accessdate=1 January 2007}}</ref> In 2007, the club launched the [[Back to the Shed campaign]] to improve the atmosphere at home matches, with notable success. According to [[Home Office]] statistics, 126 Chelsea fans were arrested for football-related offences during the [[2009–10 in English football|2009–10]] season, the third highest in the division, and 27 [[banning order]]s were issued, the fifth-highest in the division.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.homeoffice.gov.uk/publications/crime/football-arrests-banning-orders/fbo-2009-10?view=Binary |title=Statistics on football-related arrests and banning orders |accessdate=14 May 2011 |date=November 2010 |publisher=Home Office |format=PDF |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110317054025/http://www.homeoffice.gov.uk/publications/crime/football-arrests-banning-orders/fbo-2009-10?view=Binary |archivedate=17 March 2011 }}</ref>
===Rivalries=== {{Main|West London derby|Arsenal F.C.–Chelsea F.C. rivalry|Chelsea F.C.–Tottenham Hotspur F.C. rivalry|Chelsea F.C.–Leeds United F.C. rivalry}} Chelsea have long-standing rivalries with North London clubs [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] and [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=312–318}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2015/apr/22/a-brief-history-of-the-arsenal-chelsea-rivalry-and-why-it-matters|title=A brief history of the Arsenal-Chelsea rivalry and why it matters|work=The Guardian|date=22 April 2015|accessdate=7 December 2015}}</ref> A [[Chelsea F.C.–Leeds United F.C. rivalry|strong rivalry]] with [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]] dates back to several heated and controversial matches in the 1960s and 1970s, particularly the [[1970 FA Cup Final]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=321–325}}</ref> More recently a rivalry with [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] has grown following repeated clashes in cup competitions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talksport.co.uk/magazine/features/2011-05-19/peterborough-v-mk-dons-liverpool-v-chelsea-stoke-v-cardiff-six-best-modern-football-rivalries|title=Six very modern football rivalries|work=TalkSport|accessdate=23 May 2011|date=19 May 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130525205127/http://www.talksport.co.uk/magazine/features/2011-05-19/peterborough-v-mk-dons-liverpool-v-chelsea-stoke-v-cardiff-six-best-modern-football-rivalries|archive-date=25 May 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2015/oct/29/chelsea-liverpool-field-notes-rivalry|title=A brief guide to Chelsea's rivalry with Liverpool|work=The Guardian|date=29 October 2015|accessdate=4 December 2015}}</ref> Chelsea's fellow [[West London derby|West London]] sides [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]], [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] and [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] are generally not considered major rivals, as matches have only taken place intermittently due to the clubs often being in separate divisions.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |page=311}}</ref>
A 2004 survey by Planetfootball.com found that Chelsea fans consider their main rivalries to be with (in descending order): [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], Tottenham Hotspur and [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]. In the same survey, fans of Arsenal, Fulham, Leeds United, QPR, Tottenham, and West Ham United named Chelsea as one of their three main rivals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefootballnetwork.net/main/s120/st44186.htm|title=Football Rivalries: The Complete Results|publisher=Planetfootball.com|accessdate=2 January 2007}}</ref> In a 2008 poll conducted by the [[Football Fans Census]], Chelsea fans named Liverpool, Arsenal and Manchester United as their most disliked clubs. ==Records== {{details|List of Chelsea F.C. records and statistics}} [[File:Frank Lampard'13-14.JPG|thumb|200px|[[Frank Lampard]] is Chelsea's all-time highest goalscorer.]] Chelsea's highest appearance-maker is ex-captain [[Ron Harris (footballer)|Ron Harris]], who played in 795 competitive games for the club between 1961 and 1980.<ref name="stats">For the appearance and goalscoring records of all Chelsea players, see {{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=399–410 }}</ref> Four other players made more than 500 appearances for the club: [[Peter Bonetti]] (729; 1959–79), [[John Terry]] (717; 1998–2017), [[Frank Lampard]] (648; 2001–2014) and [[John Hollins]] (592; 1963–1975 and 1983–1984). With 103 [[Cap (sport)|caps]] (101 while at the club) for England, Lampard is Chelsea's most capped international player. Every starting player in Chelsea's 57 games of the 2013–14 season was a full international – a new club record.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2014/08/pre-match-briefing--burnley-v-chelsea.html|title=Pre-Match Briefing: Burnley v Chelsea – part one|publisher=Chelsea FC|accessdate=18 August 2014}}</ref>

==Ownership and finances== [[File:Roman Abramovich 2.jpg|thumb|200px|Chelsea owner [[Roman Abramovich]]]] Chelsea Football Club were founded by [[Gus Mears]] in 1905. After his death in 1912, his descendants continued to own the club until 1982, when [[Ken Bates]] bought the club from Mears' great-nephew [[Brian Mears]] for £1. Bates bought a controlling stake in the club and floated Chelsea on the [[Alternative Investment Market|AIM]] stock exchange in March 1996.<ref>{{cite web |title=UK Football Clubs on the UK Stock Markets |url=http://www.footballeconomy.com/stats/stats_turnover_09.htm |publisher=Football Economy |accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> In the mid-1990s Chelsea fan and businessman [[Matthew Harding]] became a director and loaned the club £26 million to build the new North Stand and invest in new players.<ref>{{cite news |title=The battle of Stamford Bridge |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/the-battle-of-stamford-bridge-1581435.html |work=The Independent|date=11 November 1995 |accessdate=20 July 2019}}</ref>
In July 2003, [[Roman Abramovich]] purchased just over 50% of Chelsea Village plc's share capital, including Bates' 29.5% stake, for £30 million and over the following weeks bought out most of the remaining 12,000 shareholders at 35 pence per share, completing a £140 million takeover. Other shareholders at the time of the takeover included the [[Matthew Harding]] estate (21%), [[BSkyB]] (9.9%) and various anonymous offshore trusts.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bates sells off Chelsea to a Russian billionaire |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2406994/Bates-sells-off-Chelsea-to-a-Russian-billionaire.html |work=The Daily Telegraph|date=7 February 2003 |accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref> After passing the 90% share threshold, Abramovich took the club back into private hands, delisting it from the AIM on 22 August 2003.
At the time of the Abramovich takeover, the club also had debts of around £100 million, which included a ten-year £75 million [[Eurobond (external bond)|Eurobond]] taken out in 1997 by the Bates regime to buy the freehold of Stamford Bridge and finance the redevelopment of the stadium. The 9% interest on the loan cost the club around £7 million a year and according to [[Bruce Buck]], Chelsea were struggling to pay an instalment due in July 2003.<ref>{{cite news |title=Roman Abramovich clears Chelsea debt |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2329097/Roman-Abramovich-clears-Chelsea-debt.html |work=The Daily Telegraph|date=22 December 2007 |accessdate=30 June 2019}}</ref> Abramovich paid off some of this debt immediately, but the outstanding £36 million on the Eurobond was not fully repaid until 2008.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea tycoon to clear club's debt |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/3102819.stm |publisher=BBC|date=28 July 2003 |accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> Since then, the club have had no external debt.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea and United debts at record £1.5bn |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/may/20/premierleague.chelsea |work=The Guardian|date=20 May 2008 |accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref>
Abramovich changed the ownership name to Chelsea FC plc, whose ultimate parent company is Fordstam Limited, which is controlled by him.<ref>{{cite web|title=Club Information |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/page/ClubInfo/0,,10268,00.html? |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120702215947/http://www.chelseafc.com/page/ClubInfo/0%2C%2C10268%2C00.html |archivedate=2 July 2012 |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=26 June 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Chelsea are additionally funded by Abramovich via interest free [[soft loan]]s channelled through his holding company Fordstam Limited. The loans stood at £709 million in December 2009, when they were all converted to [[Equity (finance)|equity]] by Abramovich, leaving the club themselves debt free,<ref>{{cite news |title=Roman Abramovich turns £340m of debt into equity as Chelsea loss falls |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/dec/30/roman-abramovich-chelsea-debts-accounts |work=The Guardian|date=30 December 2009 |accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Statement on Club Finance|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2055740 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20140423225239/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2055740 |url-status=dead |archive-date=23 April 2014 |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=23 April 2014}}</ref> although the debt remains with Fordstam.<ref>{{cite news |title=Roman Abramovich still owed £726m under complex Chelsea structure |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/may/19/roman-abramovich-chelsea-loan-debt |work=The Guardian|date=19 May 2010 |accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref>
Chelsea did not turn a profit in the first nine years of Abramovich's ownership, and made record losses of £140m in June 2005.<ref name="first profit">{{cite news |title=Chelsea FC record first Abramovich-era profit|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/20270934 |publisher=BBC|date=9 November 2012 |accessdate=25 February 2015}}</ref> In November 2012, Chelsea announced a profit of £1.4 million for the year ending 30 June 2012, the first time the club had made a profit under Abramovich's ownership.<ref name="first profit"/><ref>{{cite news |title=CHELSEA FC ANNOUNCES ANNUAL PROFIT |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2975285/title/chelsea-fc-announces-annual-profit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121111072755/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2975285/title/chelsea-fc-announces-annual-profit |archivedate=11 November 2012 |publisher=Chelsea FC|date=9 November 2012 |accessdate=9 November 2012}}</ref> This was followed by a loss in 2013 and then their highest ever profit of £18.4 million for the year to June 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea FC reports a record £18m in annual profit|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-30045978|accessdate=14 November 2014|publisher=BBC|date=14 November 2014}}</ref> In 2018 Chelsea announced a record after-tax profit of £62 million.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea FC financial results show record revenues|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/news/2018/12/31/chelsea-fc-financial-results-show-record-revenues|accessdate=20 July 2019|publisher=Chelseafc.com|date=31 December 2018}}</ref>
Chelsea have been described as a global brand; a 2012 report by [[Brand Finance]] ranked Chelsea fifth among football brands and valued the club's brand value at US$398 million – an increase of 27% from the previous year, also valuing them at US$10 million more than the sixth best brand, London rivals Arsenal – and gave the brand a strength rating of AA (very strong).<ref>{{cite web |title=Top 20 most Valuable Football Club Brands |url=http://www.brandfinance.com/images/upload/top_30_european_football_brands_2011_final_website.pdf |publisher=Brand Finance |accessdate=26 June 2012 |date=May 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Top 30 Football Club Brands |url=http://www.brandfinance.com/images/upload/brandfinance_football_brands_2012.pdf |publisher=Brand Finance |accessdate=4 October 2011 |date=September 2011 }}</ref> In 2016, ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine ranked Chelsea the seventh most valuable football club in the world, at £1.15 billion ($1.66 billion).<ref name="Forbes Valuation">{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mikeozanian/2017/06/06/the-worlds-most-valuable-soccer-teams-2017/#54c9255a77ea|title=The World's Most Valuable Soccer Teams 2017|last1=Ozanian|first1=Mike|date=6 June 2017|website=Forbes|accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref> {{as of|2016}}, Chelsea are ranked eighth in the [[Deloitte Football Money League]] with an annual commercial revenue of £322.59 million.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea – Deloitte Football Money League|url=http://www2.deloitte.com/uk/en/pages/sports-business-group/articles/deloitte-football-money-league.html |work=Deloitte |accessdate=21 January 2016 }}</ref>
The club's recent accounting records highlight £26.6m they have lost in compensation to former head coach [[Antonio Conte]] for sacking and to pay off his backroom staff and the legal costs that followed.<ref>{{cite_web|url=https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11668/11902943/antonio-conte-sacking-cost-chelsea-26-6m-accounts-show|title= Antonio Conte sacking cost Chelsea £26.6m, accounts show|accessdate=7 January 2019|website=Sky Sports}}</ref>
===Sponsorship=== [[File:Sergio Perez 2012 Canadian GP - Crop.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Sauber|Sauber F1 Team]], an official partner of the club, displaying the Chelsea crest]] Chelsea's kit has been manufactured by [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] since July 2017. Previously, the kit was manufactured by [[Adidas]], which was originally contracted to supply the club's kit from 2006 to 2018. The partnership was extended in October 2010 in a deal worth £160 million over eight years.<ref>{{cite news |date=22 October 2010 |title=Chelsea manager Carlo Ancelotti puts his faith in elder statesman Didier Drogba |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/chelsea/8081823/Chelsea-manager-Carlo-Ancelotti-puts-his-faith-in-elder-statesman-Didier-Drogba.html |work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref> This deal was again extended in June 2013 in a deal worth £300 million over another ten years.<ref>{{cite news |date=22 June 2013 |title=Chelsea and Adidas Announce Extension of Global Partnership |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/3216081/title/chelsea-and-adidas-announce-extension-of-global-partnership |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130624022143/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/3216081/title/chelsea-and-adidas-announce-extension-of-global-partnership |archivedate=24 June 2013 |publisher=Chelsea FC|accessdate=22 June 2013}}</ref> In May 2016, Adidas announced that by mutual agreement, the kit sponsorship would end six years early on 30 June 2017.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-36266181 |title=Adidas ends Chelsea sponsorship six years early |date=11 May 2016 |publisher=BBC |access-date=28 December 2016}}</ref> Chelsea had to pay £40m in compensation to Adidas. In October 2016, Nike was announced as the new kit sponsor, in a deal worth £900m over 15 years, until 2032.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/oct/13/chelsea-new-kit-deal-nike-60m |title=Chelsea confirm kit deal with Nike worth £60m a season until 2032 |date=13 October 2016 |work=The Guardian |access-date=28 December 2016}}</ref> Previously, the kit was manufactured by [[Umbro]] (1975–81), [[Le Coq Sportif]] (1981–86), The Chelsea Collection (1986–87), Umbro (1987–2006), and Adidas (2006–2017).
Chelsea's first shirt sponsor was [[Gulf Air]], agreed during the 1983–84 season. The club were then sponsored by Grange Farms, [[Peter Foster|Bai Lin Tea]] and [[Simod]] before a long-term deal was signed with [[Commodore International]] in 1989; [[Amiga]], an offshoot of Commodore, also appeared on the shirts. Chelsea were subsequently sponsored by [[Coors Brewing Company|Coors]] beer (1994–97), [[Autoglass]] (1997–2001), [[Emirates (airline)|Emirates]] (2001–05), [[Samsung Mobile]] (2005–08) and [[Samsung Group|Samsung]] (2008–15).<ref name=yokohama/><ref>{{cite news |date=2 May 2005 |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/article387503.ece|title=Clubs to cash in on mobile advertising |work=The Times |location=UK |accessdate=21 January 2010 |first=Ashling |last=O'Connor}}</ref> Chelsea's current shirt sponsor is [[Yokohama Rubber Company|Yokohama Tyres]]. Worth £40 million per year, the deal is second in English football to [[Chevrolet]]'s £50 million-per-year sponsorship of Manchester United.<ref name=yokohama>{{cite news|title=Chelsea sign £40m-per-year shirt deal with Japanese tyre company|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31653343|accessdate=27 February 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=26 February 2015}}</ref>
Following the introduction of sleeve sponsors in the Premier League, Chelsea had [[Alliance Tire Company|Alliance Tyres]] as their first sleeve sponsor in the [[2017–18 Chelsea F.C. season|2017–18 season]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2017/07/alliance-tyres-to-appear-on-2017-18-sleeves.html |title=Alliance Tyres to appear on 2017/18 sleeves |website=chelseafc.com |accessdate=22 July 2017|date=22 July 2017}}</ref> For the [[2018–19 Chelsea F.C. season|2018–19 season]], they have [[Hyundai Motor Company]] as the new sleeve sponsor.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/news/2018/6/11/chelsea-and-hyundai-begin-new-partnership |title=Chelsea and Hyundai Begin New Partnership |website=chelseafc.com |accessdate=11 June 2018|date=11 June 2018}}</ref> The club also has a variety of other sponsors and official partners, which include [[Carabao Energy Drink|Carabao]], [[Delta Air Lines]], [[Beats by Dre]], [[Singha]], [[EA Sports]], [[Rexona]], [[Hublot]], [[Ericsson]], [[William Hill (bookmaker)|William Hill]], [[Levy Restaurants]], [[Wipro]], [[International Beverages Trading|Grand Royal Whisky]], [[Bangkok Bank]], [[Guangzhou R&F F.C.|Guangzhou R&F]], [[Mobinil]], [[IndusInd Bank]], and Ole777.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/the-club/sponsors.html|title=Sponsors and Partners |website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=4 November 2014}}</ref>
==Popular culture== [[File:Chelsea double winner 2009-10.JPG|left|thumb|200px|Chelsea parade through the streets of Fulham and Chelsea after winning their league and cup double, May 2010]] In 1930, Chelsea featured in one of the earliest football films, ''[[The Great Game (1930 film)|The Great Game]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0020936/ |title=The Great Game |website=Internet Movie Database |accessdate=1 October 2007 }}</ref> One-time Chelsea centre forward, [[Jack Cock]], who by then was playing for [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]], was the star of the film and several scenes were shot at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], including on the pitch, the boardroom, and the [[dressing room]]s. It included guest appearances by then-Chelsea players [[Andrew Nesbit Wilson|Andrew Wilson]], [[George Mills (footballer)|George Mills]], and [[Sam Millington]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=120–121}}</ref> Owing to the notoriety of the [[Chelsea Headhunters]], a [[football firm]] associated with the club, Chelsea have also featured in films about football [[hooliganism]], including 2004's ''[[The Football Factory (film)|The Football Factory]]''.<ref>{{cite news |date=10 May 2004 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/film/3687227.stm |title=Football firms hit the film circuit |work=BBC Sport |accessdate=25 January 2007 |first=Steve |last=Hawkes}}</ref> Chelsea also appear in the [[Hindi]] film ''[[Jhoom Barabar Jhoom]]''.<ref>{{cite news |date=25 September 2006 |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/report.asp?NewsID=1055099 |title=Chelsea teams up with Yash Raj Films |newspaper=DNA India |accessdate=1 January 2007 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930015215/http://www.dnaindia.com/report.asp?NewsID=1055099 |archivedate=30 September 2007 }}</ref> In April 2011, [[Montenegro|Montenegrin]] comedy series ''Nijesmo mi od juče'' made an episode in which Chelsea play against [[FK Sutjeska Nikšić]] for qualification of the [[UEFA Champions League]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nijesmomiodjuce.com/nijesmo-mi-od-juce-novosti/epizoda-chelsea-u-gledajte-onlajn-sekciji/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130830104319/http://www.nijesmomiodjuce.com/nijesmo-mi-od-juce-novosti/epizoda-chelsea-u-gledajte-onlajn-sekciji/|archivedate=30 August 2013|title=Nijesmo mi od Juce – Novosti – Epizode – Chelsea u "gledajte onlajn" sekciji|publisher=nijesmomiodjuce.com|accessdate=23 April 2014|language=Montenegrin}}</ref>
Up until the 1950s, the club had a long-running association with the [[music hall]]s; their underachievement often provided material for comedians such as [[George Robey]].<ref>{{cite news |date=30 September 2002 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2002/sep/30/match.sport7 |title=Di Canio has last laugh at Chelsea comedy store |work=The Guardian |accessdate=14 July 2011 |first=Scott |last=Murray}}</ref> It culminated in comedian Norman Long's release of a [[Novelty song|comic song]] in 1933, ironically titled "On the Day That Chelsea Went and Won the Cup", the lyrics of which describe a series of bizarre and improbable occurrences on the hypothetical day when Chelsea finally won a trophy.<ref name="glanville"/> In [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s 1935 film ''[[The 39 Steps (1935 film)|The 39 Steps]]'', Mr Memory claims that Chelsea last won the Cup in 63 BC, "in the presence of the [[List of Roman emperors|Emperor]] [[Nero]]."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0026029/quotes |title=The 39 Steps |website=Internet Movie Database |accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref> Scenes in a 1980 episode of ''[[Minder (TV series)|Minder]]'' were filmed during a real match at Stamford Bridge between Chelsea and [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] with Terry McCann (played by [[Dennis Waterman]]) standing on the terraces.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.minder.org/episodeguide/S02E12_AllAboutScoringInnit.htm |title=All About Scoring, Innit? |publisher=Minder.org |accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref>
The song "[[Blue Is the Colour (song)|Blue is the Colour]]" was released as a single in the build-up to the [[1972 Football League Cup Final|1972 League Cup Final]], with all members of Chelsea's first team squad singing; it reached number five in the [[UK Singles Chart]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.officialcharts.com/search/singles/Garden%20Party |title=Blue Is The Colour |work=[[Official Charts Company]] |accessdate=21 January 2007 }}</ref> The song has since been adopted as an anthem by a number of other sports teams around the world, including the [[Vancouver Whitecaps (1986–2010)|Vancouver Whitecaps]] (as "White is the Colour")<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vancourier.com/issues02/045202/sports.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080103163706/http://www.vancourier.com/issues02/045202/sports.html |archivedate=3 January 2008 |title=Caps' 'Proclaim' season opener |work=Vancouver Courier |accessdate=21 January 2007}}</ref> and the [[Saskatchewan Roughriders]] (as "Green is the Colour").<ref>{{cite news |date=26 November 2009 |url=http://www2.canada.com/calgaryherald/news/city/story.html?id=2a537f58-d315-495f-8ba5-0359dd597ed9 |title=Riders fans enjoy musical edge |work=Calgary Herald |accessdate=5 May 2014 |first=Stephen |last=Hunt |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140505195145/http://www2.canada.com/calgaryherald/news/city/story.html?id=2a537f58-d315-495f-8ba5-0359dd597ed9 |archivedate=5 May 2014 }}</ref> In the build-up to the [[1997 FA Cup Final]], the song "Blue Day", performed by [[Suggs (singer)|Suggs]] and members of the Chelsea squad, reached number 22 in the UK charts.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.officialcharts.com/search/singles/Rock%20Me%20Good |title=Blue Day |work=[[Official Charts Company]] |accessdate=11 September 2016 }}</ref> {{clear}}

== Controversy ==
=== Sexual abuse === {{Main|United Kingdom football sexual abuse scandal}}
In August 2019, Chelsea's board apologised "unreservedly" after a report found that during the 1970s the club's chief scout, [[United Kingdom football sexual abuse scandal|Eddie Heath]], groomed and abused young boys aged between 10 and 17. The report, which was led by Charles Geekie QC, concluded that Heath was a "prolific and manipulative sexual abuser" and had been able to operate "unchallenged". The report was also heavily critical of the club's former assistant manager [[Dario Gradi]], who was accused of failing to tell more senior club staff about an allegation regarding the sexual conduct of Heath which had been brought to him by the father of a young player.
In light of the report, Chelsea announced that it was committed to assessing compensation claims for victims.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/49251891|title=Chelsea apology over ex-chief scout Eddie Heath's 'unchallenged' sex abuse|date=2019-08-06|access-date=2019-08-06|language=en-GB}}</ref>
=== Racial abuse === In May 2018, the club appointed [[Barnardo's]] to oversee an independent investigation into the allegations of racism. The complaints were initially brought by three former youth-team footballers who claimed that Gwyn Williams and Graham Rix subjected young black players to explicit racial abuse, during their time at the club in the 1990s.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/may/09/chelsea-barnardos-investigate-racism-claims-gwyn-williams-graham-rix|title=Chelsea bring in Barnardo's to investigate claims of racism by coaches|last=Taylor|first=Daniel|date=2018-05-09|work=The Guardian|access-date=2019-08-06|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
In August 2019, Barnardo's published the findings of its review. The report concluded that "black players were subjected to a daily tirade of racial abuse".<ref name=":0" /> Following the publication of the report, the club issued a statement in which it acknowledged that "Barnardo's found that there is overwhelming information indicating that a member of staff at the club during the 1980s and 1990s subjected young players to bullying and racially abuse behaviour".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2019/08/06/dario-gradi-accused-failing-prevent-abuse-former-chelsea-coach/|title=Dario Gradi accused of failing to prevent abuse by former Chelsea coach and serial sexual offender Eddie Heath|last=Wilson|first=Jeremy|date=2019-08-06|work=The Daily Telegraph|access-date=2019-08-06|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref>
